benchmark_details.name: Hatevolution: What Static Benchmarks Don’t Tell Us
benchmark_details.overview: This paper investigates the impact of evolving language on hate speech benchmarking, suggesting the need for time-sensitive linguistic benchmarks, given that current static benchmarks do not account for language evolution.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To empirically evaluate the robustness of language models across evolving hate speech detection tasks.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: Static benchmarks do not account for the evolving nature of hate speech language.

data.source: Publicly available datasets like Singapore Online Attacks and NeoBench for hate speech detection.
data.annotation: Manual annotation by experts with substantial agreement (Cohen’s Kappa = 0.67).

methodology.calculation: The macro F1 score is calculated across time-sensitive evaluations.
methodology.interpretation: High and stable time-sensitive F1 scores indicate better adaptation to evolving contexts of hate speech.
methodology.baseline_results: Baseline scores from established hate speech models.

targeted_risks.harm: Potential misalignment could lead to overestimation of language models’ safety.
